This is a test with the integrated Jitsi Meet video. Anybody happen to be here and interested in testing?
Click to join video call

Jitsi Meet
Join a WebRTC video conference powered by the Jitsi Videobridge
Seems like it may have good potential. (Worth testing with a group)
I can try. No video though.

Jitsi looks cool! It's basically an open-source equivalent of Google Hangouts (from what I could see). Supports screen sharing, streaming, YouTube, and all with the benefit (over Zoom) of doing it all through your browser (lower barrier of entry for people (i.e. no need to install third-party software). And it's open-source!
This can also be useful potentially when troubleshooting with someone -- drop in a quick video link, share screen and walk through it in real time.
Absolutely
I have clicked the link, and after getting a prompt to allow the browser to use the mic/camera, a session has started. Nobody else was there of course, so I cannot verify whether it "works" or not.
...I am very for it - especially since it's open-source.
Are meeting agendas/templates private, or can I publicly discuss something I read there?
Anyone? ^
I don't think they're private are they? They have links posted in public Gitter

Hmm, so I saw something in the agenda for this week, and so waited to hear it mentioned in the meeting, but it wasn't. When I checked the agenda afterwards it had been removed (along with a bunch of other stuff because the meeting was trimmed down to the essentials for the upcoming release). When I looked at the template for the weekly meeting, it's still there (so I guess it'll be discussed next week (assuming it's not postponed again). But because it was deleted from this week's agenda, and because I don't think the templates are public, and because I don't want to jump the gun on an announcement either during the meeting or as a result of the meeting, I'm not sure whether I can/should ask about it...?
You could try a PM to someone
Sorry, DM
Yeah, might try that I guess

@BWPanda (Peter)

I'm assuming that you are talking about one of the PMC agenda items awaiting a blog post. I have no inside information about these items, but have heard some of them discussed briefly before or after a meeting. I don't believe that they are top secret (or they wouldn't even be on the template), but I would personally refrain from public discussion until there is some kind of announcement.
Indeed. I agree. Just very curious, and slightly concerned...
Now you've got me curious.

Sorry all. It's not my place to say anything, and I certainly don't want to start rumours (especially without knowing much detail myself). Considering it was on the agenda, I'm sure we'll be hearing something soon.

Hi, Bryan Ollendyke. Welcome to the Backdrop CMS community on Zulip. I'm your friendly neighborhood Dragonbot. Try '@Dragonbot help' for a list of things I can help you with. There are lots of friendly humans that hang around here, so please feel free to ask questions.

@Bryan Ollendyke the main reason to switch to Zulip from Gitter was the threaded discussions (Gitter did not support that) ...and the free version of Slack does not retain chat history, whereas Zulip does (their free open-source plan that is).

@Bryan Ollendyke See https://github.com/backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org/issues/587 and https://github.com/backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org/issues/629 for full discussion/reasoning...

Discussion: Alternatives to Gitter · Issue #587 · backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org
I am opening this issue, because the discussion of moving off of Gitter keeps coming up from time to time and we don't currently have a good issue to capture the thoughts and history of this di...
Gitter vs. Zulip · Issue #629 · backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org
This is a follow-up to the discussion that has been happening this topic: #587 - Discussion: Alternatives to Gitter A little over a week ago, we opened dedicated Zulip instance for testing and expe...

I was trying to remove both the words "theming" and "usable", but keep the intent the same
I removed "custom" because you mentioned that people shouldn't even need to modify anything in HTML/CSS
even if they aren't making a custom theme, if the ones they download aren't "good enough" they'll still need to do some development
How about something more along the lines of do some basic styling without needing to touch any files?
Thanks!
OMG 4 years old

oadaeh (Jason Flatt) said:

How about something more along the lines of do some basic styling without needing to touch any files?

"Without having to touch any files" is the key part, though it's also important that they shouldn't have to do any basic styling either. Can you imagine if I had to shop for clothes like that? I go shopping for clothes, and I walk into a room with racks and racks of white T-shirts. The clerk tells me I can do anything I want! Cut them to any shape, dye them any color or pattern, emboss them with any ornaments or buttons I want. But I don't know how to competently do any of that! I just want to be able to point to a shirt and say "that one looks nice" and buy it.

That's what I think we should offer for themes. Give people some choices that they can point to and say "that one" without forcing it to be any more complicated than that.
That's what I meant by basic styling. I wouldn't consider the other the be basic.

Is that right?

No! :laughter_tears:
Incomprehensible, it seems
I'm pretty sure that someone, somewhere understands it - ;-)

One more try?:
When you create a layout a node path like node/% this tells layout create a context for nodes. When you go to node/5 layouts loads data from node NID 5 into that context, so that that node becomes available to every block in that layout. But if you layout path was notanode/anypath this wouldnt happen. Your blocks would have no access to node data. Blocks requiring node data would refuse to show up. BUT with this PR, you can still make your layout path notanode/anypath, then manually add a context for nodes. WHen you visited that path, data from node NID 5 would be loaded into that context. Blocks requiring node data would show up.

Anyone that is interested in helping with Backdrop LIVE, we are having a meeting now. See the Event Planning Stream for details.

The only problem I have of someone sharing their screen for the majority of the meeting, is that anyone who talks and has their camera off in basically invisible. Without screen sharing, users who are talking are shown with their name in the bottom-left. Users without video have just their name shown on the screen when they're talking. With screen sharing, users with video are displayed as a thumbnail in the top-right, but users without video are hidden altogether. This makes it really hard to know who's talking if you don't already know people's voices by heart.

In other words, screen sharing means people without video don't have their name displayed on screen when talking. This isn't a criticism of whoever's screen sharing, but rather a problem with Zoom itself. Having said that, maybe it's worth not screen sharing when not necessary so we can see who's talking and avoid this problem...?

Case in point: YouTube - Backdrop Weekly Meetings @StPaulTim and someone else are talking, but I don't know who the other person is (I probably should know, but I'm afraid I'm not that familiar with everyone yet).
Good point! I guess, sometimes people just forget to turn off screensharing again when it's not needed anymore.

It should be noted: that's a problem with zoom (nothing displayed if camera off). I agree, it's hard to figure out who's talking, when screensharing is on and several people have their camera off. Personally (as audience) I find it easier to follow a discussion, if all participants are displayed. But I admit, it might be easier for the participants if one person shares the screen (either with opened issues or the agenda).

In this case, I left the screen sharing active on purpose. The idea was that it was better to show the agenda than to not look at anything.

However, I understand the issue of not knowing who is talking. I don't think that was an issue for those of us on the call at the time, but it might be harder for those not actively participating. I will keep this in mind in the future and turn off screen sharing when it's not needed - unless we find a better solution for tracking who is talking.
Thanks for feedback

Following up on @Laryn's mention of User Time Zone Tokens: I've added a field formatter for core Date fields to the main branch at https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/utz_tokens. I'd be interested in any feedback or testing before I do a proper release (and, of course, encourage using its functionality for Backdrop meeting notices). Like the original tokens-only version, the field formatter can use the system date formats; it handles date ranges and and can show dates in the user time zone for both authenticated and anonymous users. (H/T to @indigoxela, whose Client Side Date Formatter module was immensely helpful in figuring out aspects of this.)

Why not trying to combine forces? :laughing:
I'd love to!

Interesting! So, additionally to my approach to let the browser take over the date format (international date formats are a challenge), your approach also provides to set the format? Don't see it yet: does this respect localized date formats in any way?

As I mentioned, that was a very useful module in understanding how to do this. But I needed fairly different behavior in the date formatter, needing to handle PHP format strings and date ranges (which are not part of cs_date_formatter). And UTZ Tokens is (probably) not as localization-savvy as CS Date Formatter (though I would welcome guidance, input, PRs, on making it so).

The way it handles localized date formats is to allow translation of format strings. (Which is not much, admittedly.) But I needed it to be based on PHP format strings (in part for backward compatibility with a Drupal site that uses the unreleased Drupal version.)

So you provide one format for all displays? Hm. That's what I intentionally did not do, because date formats can be soo different in different countries. But date ranges would be a win (I skipped fiddling with that out of lazyness... ehm, not lazy, it's K.I.S.S. :grinning: )
Not one format for all displays. The user can select from any of the system formats, or can enter a custom format.
"User" means author, or Backdrop user, or visitor?
Sorry, let me rephrase: the person configuring the content type displays can select from any of the system formats or can enter a custom format.
The visitor doesn't get to choose individual formats per-display.

Basically, it's the same choice that the core Date module offers, with the addition of letting one create a custom string directly in the formatter settings, and with the minus that date ranges are not automatically shortened by dropping duplicate elements (though I'd like to add that in the future).

Hm, so the formats are not "internationalized"? I'm writing that as a visitor, who always has to think what that am/pm time might mean - I'm used to the 24-hour system. And then there's the day/month/year vs. month/day/year problem - where I'm completely forced to guessing. :stuck_out_tongue_wink:

Yes, that's right, and I totally agree that it would be nicer to be fully interntionalized in that way. (Having lived in Germany briefly, I became used to the 24-hour-time and DD/MM/YY format and find them far more logical.) Allowing translation of PHP format strings seemed like it offered a possibility of internationalization.
BTW, the ranges aren't shortened in cs_date_formatter either - that's pretty tricky.
Yup. Why I left that for the future.
What would be your approach for internationalized formats in utz_tokens? How to choose the right format for anonymous - without providing a load of formats and mappings?

I don't really know. I'm also living with my own backward-compatibility issues: the first version didn't handle anonymous users, doing everything in PHP on the server side; the last version handles anonymous users by doing everything in JS on the client side, but for compatibility offers the old behavior as a option. So now I'm stuck with server-side code and client-side code that does the same thing. (Or I could just force everyone to the client-side solution, relying on there only being a couple of installs right now.)

On the Drupal site that uses the Drupal version of the module, we get around the different month/day order by never using MM/DD/YYYY formats. (Still uses the English spellings of the month, but at least it's not ambiguous.)
